<td style="padding-top:20px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Good morning. </strong>Alexa, define the word “juxtaposition”: As nearly all pandemic restrictions lift today in England, British Prime Minister Boris Johnson will self-isolate for the next week and a half after coming into contact with someone who was infected with Covid-19. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Such is the New Normal. </p>

<div class="c6 " style="margin-bottom:7px">
<!-- <![endif]-->
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
SOCIAL MEDIA
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/07/18/facebook-biden-war-words-vaccine-misinformation?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
Biden to Facebook: Actually, It Is Your Fault
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/07/18/facebook-biden-war-words-vaccine-misinformation?utm_source=morning_brew" style="text-decoration:none;border:none;" target="_blank" class="">
<img alt="Robin Williams in Good Will Hunting" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC81ODIwL2dvb2Rfd2lsbF9odW50aW5nLmpwZWciLCJidWNrZXQiOiJvc2xvLXByb2R1Y3Rpb24iLCJlZGl0cyI6eyJyZXNpemUiOnsid2lkdGgiOjEwMDAsImhlaWdodCI6bnVsbH19fQ==">
</a>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em>Good Will Hunting</em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Facebook and the Biden administration are going at it like two bighorn sheep on <em>Planet Earth</em>.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">The social media company <a href="https://www.nytimes.com/2021/07/17/technology/facebook-vaccine-misinformation.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">pushed back</a> on Saturday against increasing criticism from the White House that the company is allowing the spread of Covid-19 vaccine misinformation.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Some of that criticism:</p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li aria-level="1" style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>President Biden told reporters that social media firms were “killing people.” </span></li>
<li aria-level="1" style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>WH Press Secretary Jen Psaki said health misinformation on social media is “leading to people not taking the vaccine, and people are dying as a result.”</span></li>
<li aria-level="1" style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>Also last week, Surgeon General Dr. Vivek Murthy released his </span><span><a href="https://www.nytimes.com/2021/07/15/us/politics/surgeon-general-vaccine-misinformation.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">first formal advisory</a></span><span> calling web-based vaccine misinformation “an urgent threat to public health.” </span>
</li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">No one likes to be accused of killing people, and Facebook published a <a href="https://about.fb.com/news/2021/07/support-for-covid-19-vaccines-is-high-on-facebook-and-growing/?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">blog post</a> saying it’s not to blame. “The fact is that vaccine acceptance among Facebook users in the US has increased,” the company wrote, citing a study that showed vaccine acceptance among FB users has jumped 10–15 percentage points since January. “These and other facts tell a very different story to the one promoted by the administration in recent days.” </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Big picture: </strong>The CDC has called the recent surge in Covid cases, hospitalizations, and deaths a “pandemic of the unvaccinated.” More than 97% of new hospitalizations from the Delta variant are of people who’ve not been vaccinated, the agency said. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">This isn’t a new problem. For months Facebook and other social media companies have been playing whack-a-mole with accounts that falsely claim that Covid-19 vaccines don’t work (they’ve proven highly effective in studies, including against the Delta variant). Facebook has taken some steps to limit the spread of vaccine misinformation, but the Biden administration thinks those actions have been toothless.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Bottom line: </strong>As the Delta variant spreads, the US government is desperate to revive a stalled vaccination campaign. Canada, whose vaccination rates had been lagging the US for months, <a href="https://www.bbc.com/news/world-us-canada-57869947?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">sprinted</a> past its neighbor last week. </p>

<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding-top: 12px;">

<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
CYBER
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/07/18/report-nso-group-software-used-hack-journalists-executives-phones?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
When Spyware Falls Into the Wrong Hands
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding-right:15px;padding-bottom:15px;padding-left:15px;padding-top:0px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Military-grade spyware licensed to foreign governments has been <a href="https://www.washingtonpost.com/investigations/2021/07/18/takeaways-nso-pegasus-project/?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">used to hack</a> dozens of smartphones belonging to journalists, human rights activists, and business executives since 2016.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">That’s the main takeaway from the newly launched <a href="https://www.pbs.org/wgbh/frontline/article/introducing-the-pegasus-project/?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">Pegasus Project</a>. A consortium of 17 media organizations, including the Washington Post, PBS’s Frontline, and the Guardian, released the initial findings of a deep-dive investigation into the use of Pegasus, spyware made by Israel’s NSO Group. </p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li aria-level="1" style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>The investigation was made possible by a data leak of 50,000 phone numbers that are believed to be potential targets by clients of NSO. </span></li>
<li aria-level="1" style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>Journalism nonprofit Forbidden Stories and Amnesty International had initial access to the list, then handed it over to the news outlets.</span></li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">One notable finding: </strong>Pegasus was reportedly used to hack the phone of someone in journalist Jamal Khashoggi's inner circle four days after he was murdered.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Zoom out:</strong> NSO Group called the report “full of wrong assumptions and uncorroborated theories.” But it does place more unwanted attention on the world’s most (in)famous commercial spyware provider.</p>

<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
ENTERTAINMENT
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/07/18/deepfakes-new-bourdain-doc-raise-questions-around-ai-ethics-film?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
What Anthony Bourdain Didn’t Say
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/07/18/deepfakes-new-bourdain-doc-raise-questions-around-ai-ethics-film?utm_source=morning_brew" style="text-decoration:none;border:none;" target="_blank" class="">
<img alt="Anthony Bourdain" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC81ODIxL2FudGhvbnlfYm91cmRhaW4ucG5nIiwiYnVja2V0Ijoib3Nsby1wcm9kdWN0aW9uIiwiZWRpdHMiOnsicmVzaXplIjp7IndpZHRoIjoxMDAwLCJoZWlnaHQiOm51bGx9fX0=">
</a>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em><span class="article_img_desc">Roadrunner: A Film About Anthony Bourdain (Focus Features)</span><div class="article_rail_wrapper"><div class="left-column"><div class="social_comments_app_wrapper"><div class="d-flex"><div class="share_containers"></div></div></div></div></div></em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">In <em>Roadrunner</em>, a documentary released Friday about the life of chef Anthony Bourdain, viewers <a href="https://www.washingtonpost.com/arts-entertainment/2021/07/16/anthony-bourdain-documentary-ai-deepfake/?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">hear Bourdain saying</a>, “You are successful, and I am successful, and I’m wondering: Are you happy?”</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">But Bourdain never said that. Those words were from an email the chef sent to a friend before his suicide in 2018—one of three lines in the film manufactured by artificial intelligence software under the direction of filmmaker Morgan Neville. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Neville <a href="https://www.gq.com/story/anthony-bourdain-morgan-neville-roadrunner-documentary?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">told GQ</a> that he received permission to recreate Bourdain’s voice from Bourdain’s literary executor and his widow “just to make sure people were cool with that.” Neville said he used the AI technique because it was “important to make Tony’s words come alive.”</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">But Neville’s sloppy approach has come under fire. Bourdain’s second ex-wife, Ottavia Busia, <a href="https://twitter.com/OttaviaBourdain/status/1415889455005716485?s=20" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">denied</a> that she said Bourdain would’ve been “cool” with it. And WBUR film critic Sean Burns, frustrated that the use of AI wasn’t initially disclosed, <a href="https://twitter.com/SeanMBurns/status/1415724473802690564?s=20" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">tweeted</a>, “I feel like this tells you all you need to know about the ethics of the people behind this project.”</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Bottom line: </strong>The deepfaking of Anthony Bourdain's voice has <a href="https://www.newyorker.com/culture/annals-of-gastronomy/the-ethics-of-a-deepfake-anthony-bourdain-voice?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">raised questions</a> about the ethics of using synthetic media in film, which won’t be resolved soon. </p>

<tr>
<td style="padding-top: 12px;">

<img alt="" style="display: inline-block; width: 25px" width="25" src="https://media.sailthru.com/5z8/1k4/4/2/5e86576e04837.jpg">

<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Instead of hyped-up billionaires and endless stock picks, you’ll <strong style="color:#000">understand how today's business practices, market dynamics, tax policies, and more impact you with real-time news and analysis.</strong> Their instant market data and insights will help you take action immediately—no matter your investing experience.</p>

</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/07/18/key-performance-indicators-july-19?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
Key Performance Indicators

</h1>

<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/07/18/key-performance-indicators-july-19?utm_source=morning_brew" style="text-decoration:none;border:none;" target="_blank" class="">
<img alt="A photograph of a modern WeWork office filled with tables, chairs, and couches. A young man sits on a couch with a mask on, and other people are seen on their laptops at tables in the background." style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC81NTEyL3dld29yay5qcGVnIiwiYnVja2V0Ijoib3Nsby1wcm9kdWN0aW9uIiwiZWRpdHMiOnsicmVzaXplIjp7IndpZHRoIjoxMDAwLCJoZWlnaHQiOm51bGx9fX0=">
</a>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em>WeWork</em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Stat: </strong>Masayoshi Son, the CEO of SoftBank and major WeWork investor, once calculated that the coworking company would be worth $10 trillion in a decade, according to a <a href="https://www.wsj.com/articles/wework-adam-neumann-masa-son-cult-of-we-11626474657?st=6bx9kytk2zdrryc&reflink=desktopwebshare_permalink" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">new book</a> on WeWork. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Quote:</strong> “Germany is a strong country and we will stand up to this force of nature in the short term—but also in the medium and long term, through policy that pays more regard to nature and the climate than we did in recent years.”</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">German Chancellor Angela Merkel <a href="https://apnews.com/article/europe-floods-7ddb112f034d10973b766dc028eca88e?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">vowed to address climate change</a> after touring the “surreal, ghostly” scene of a German village destroyed by flooding. Last week’s heavy rains, and subsequent flooding, killed more than 180 people across Germany and Belgium. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Read: </strong>The truth behind the Amazon mystery seeds. (<a href="https://www.theatlantic.com/science/archive/2021/07/unsolicited-seeds-china-brushing/619417/?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">The Atlantic</a>)</p>

<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
GRAB BAG
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/07/18/week-ahead-july-19?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
The Week Ahead
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>

<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/07/18/week-ahead-july-19?utm_source=morning_brew" style="text-decoration:none;border:none;" target="_blank" class="">
<img alt="Blue Origin launch" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC8zNzM2L2JsdWVfb3JpZ2luX2xhdW5jaC5qcGciLCJidWNrZXQiOiJvc2xvLXByb2R1Y3Rpb24iLCJlZGl0cyI6eyJyZXNpemUiOnsid2lkdGgiOjEwMDAsImhlaWdodCI6bnVsbH19fQ==">
</a>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em>Blue Origin</em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Gonna be a fun one.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Bezos in space: </strong>Jeff Bezos will <a href="https://www.nbcnews.com/science/space/now-jeff-bezos-turn-make-history-flight-space-rcna1435?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">blast off to space</a> in a Blue Origin rocket tomorrow, joined by a record-setting crew. Former test pilot Wally Funk, 82, would be the oldest person to reach space and Dutch teenager Oliver Daemen, 18, would be the youngest. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Earnings: </strong>Maybe the only thing more exciting than that space mission is this week’s <a href="https://www.cnbc.com/2021/07/16/earnings-could-be-the-biggest-driver-for-markets-in-the-week-ahead-as-investors-watch-bonds.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">packed slate of earnings reports</a>, which include Netflix, Coca-Cola, IBM, Twitter, Snap, Intel, J&J, and Verizon. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Tokyo 2021: </strong>The <a href="https://www.usatoday.com/story/sports/olympics/2021/07/15/2021-olympics-what-we-know-opening-ceremony-tokyo-games/7944468002/?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">opening ceremony</a> for the Olympics will air at 7am ET on Friday, though with fans banned from the stadium and many athletes not arriving until the weekend, it won’t achieve the pageantry of years past. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Everything else: </strong><em>Ted Lasso </em>season 2 hits Apple TV+ on Friday. That’s it. That’s everything else that matters. </p>

style=\"font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px\"\u003e\n\u003ca style=\"color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;\"\u003e\n\u003cfont color=\"#000000\"\u003e\nBiden to Facebook: Actually, It Is Your Fault\n\u003c/font\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003c/h1\u003e\n\u003c/td\u003e\n\u003c/tr\u003e\n\u003c/table\u003e\n\u003ca href=\"https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/07/18/facebook-biden-war-words-vaccine-misinformation?utm_source=morning_brew\" style=\"text-decoration:none;border:none;\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"\"\u003e\n\u003cimg alt=\"Robin Williams in Good Will Hunting\" style=\"display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;\" width=\"670\" class=\"story-header-image\" src=\"https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC81ODIwL2dvb2Rfd2lsbF9odW50aW5nLmpwZWciLCJidWNrZXQiOiJvc2xvLXByb2R1Y3Rpb24iLCJlZGl0cyI6eyJyZXNpemUiOnsid2lkdGgiOjEwMDAsImhlaWdodCI6bnVsbH19fQ==\"\u003e\n\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;\"\u003e\n\u003csmall\u003e\u003cem\u003eGood Will Hunting\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/small\u003e\n\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" style=\"border-collapse: collapse;\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"padding:15px\"\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eFacebook and the Biden administration are going at it like two bighorn sheep on \u003cem\u003ePlanet Earth\u003c/em\u003e.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eThe social media company \u003ca href=\"https://www.nytimes.com/2021/07/17/technology/facebook-vaccine-misinformation.html?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003epushed back\u003c/a\u003e on Saturday against increasing criticism from the White House that the company is allowing the spread of Covid-19 vaccine misinformation.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eSome of that criticism:\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli aria-level=\"1\" style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003ePresident Biden told reporters that social media firms were “killing people.” \u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003cli aria-level=\"1\" style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eWH Press Secretary Jen Psaki said health misinformation on social media is “leading to people not taking the vaccine, and people are dying as a result.”\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003cli aria-level=\"1\" style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003eAlso last week, Surgeon General Dr. Vivek Murthy released his \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://www.nytimes.com/2021/07/15/us/politics/surgeon-general-vaccine-misinformation.html?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003efirst formal advisory\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e calling web-based vaccine misinformation “an urgent threat to public health.” \u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eNo one likes to be accused of killing people, and Facebook published a \u003ca href=\"https://about.fb.com/news/2021/07/support-for-covid-19-vaccines-is-high-on-facebook-and-growing/?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eblog post\u003c/a\u003e saying it’s not to blame. “The fact is that vaccine acceptance among Facebook users in the US has increased,” the company wrote, citing a study that showed vaccine acceptance among FB users has jumped 10–15 percentage points since January. “These and other facts tell a very different story to the one promoted by the administration in recent days.” \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eBig picture: \u003c/strong\u003eThe CDC has called the recent surge in Covid cases, hospitalizations, and deaths a “pandemic of the unvaccinated.” More than 97% of new hospitalizations from the Delta variant are of people who’ve not been vaccinated, the agency said. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eThis isn’t a new problem. For months Facebook and other social media companies have been playing whack-a-mole with accounts that falsely claim that Covid-19 vaccines don’t work (they’ve proven highly effective in studies, including against the Delta variant). Facebook has taken some steps to limit the spread of vaccine misinformation, but the Biden administration thinks those actions have been toothless.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eBottom line: \u003c/strong\u003eAs the Delta variant spreads, the US government is desperate to revive a stalled vaccination campaign. Canada, whose vaccination rates had been lagging the US for months, \u003ca href=\"https://www.bbc.com/news/world-us-canada-57869947?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003esprinted\u003c/a\u003e past its neighbor last week. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c!-- SOCIAL LINKS style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eMilitary-grade spyware licensed to foreign governments has been \u003ca href=\"https://www.washingtonpost.com/investigations/2021/07/18/takeaways-nso-pegasus-project/?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eused to hack\u003c/a\u003e dozens of smartphones belonging to journalists, human rights activists, and business executives since 2016.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eThat’s the main takeaway from the newly launched \u003ca href=\"https://www.pbs.org/wgbh/frontline/article/introducing-the-pegasus-project/?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ePegasus Project\u003c/a\u003e. A consortium of 17 media organizations, including the Washington Post, PBS’s Frontline, and the Guardian, released the initial findings of a deep-dive investigation into the use of Pegasus, spyware made by Israel’s NSO Group. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli aria-level=\"1\" style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eThe investigation was made possible by a data leak of 50,000 phone numbers that are believed to be potential targets by clients of NSO. \u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003cli aria-level=\"1\" style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eJournalism nonprofit Forbidden Stories and Amnesty International had initial access to the list, then handed it over to the news outlets.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eOne notable finding: \u003c/strong\u003ePegasus was reportedly used to hack the phone of someone in journalist Jamal Khashoggi's inner circle four days after he was murdered.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eZoom out:\u003c/strong\u003e NSO Group called the report “full of wrong assumptions and uncorroborated theories.” But it does place more unwanted attention on the world’s most (in)famous commercial spyware provider.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c!-- SOCIAL LINKS --\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" style=\"border-collapse: style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;\"\u003e\n\u003csmall\u003e\u003cem\u003e\u003cspan class=\"article_img_desc\"\u003eRoadrunner: A Film About Anthony Bourdain (Focus Features)\u003c/span\u003e\u003cdiv class=\"article_rail_wrapper\"\u003e\u003cdiv class=\"left-column\"\u003e\u003cdiv class=\"social_comments_app_wrapper\"\u003e\u003cdiv class=\"d-flex\"\u003e\u003cdiv class=\"share_containers\"\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/small\u003e\n\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" style=\"border-collapse: collapse;\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"padding:15px\"\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eIn \u003cem\u003eRoadrunner\u003c/em\u003e, a documentary released Friday about the life of chef Anthony Bourdain, viewers \u003ca href=\"https://www.washingtonpost.com/arts-entertainment/2021/07/16/anthony-bourdain-documentary-ai-deepfake/?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ehear Bourdain saying\u003c/a\u003e, “You are successful, and I am successful, and I’m wondering: Are you happy?”\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eBut Bourdain never said that. Those words were from an email the chef sent to a friend before his suicide in 2018—one of three lines in the film manufactured by artificial intelligence software under the direction of filmmaker Morgan Neville. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eNeville \u003ca href=\"https://www.gq.com/story/anthony-bourdain-morgan-neville-roadrunner-documentary?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003etold GQ\u003c/a\u003e that he received permission to recreate Bourdain’s voice from Bourdain’s literary executor and his widow “just to make sure people were cool with that.” Neville said he used the AI technique because it was “important to make Tony’s words come alive.”\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eBut Neville’s sloppy approach has come under fire. Bourdain’s second ex-wife, Ottavia Busia, \u003ca href=\"https://twitter.com/OttaviaBourdain/status/1415889455005716485?s=20\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003edenied\u003c/a\u003e that she said Bourdain would’ve been “cool” with it. And WBUR film critic Sean Burns, frustrated that the use of AI wasn’t initially disclosed, \u003ca href=\"https://twitter.com/SeanMBurns/status/1415724473802690564?s=20\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003etweeted\u003c/a\u003e, “I feel like this tells you all you need to know about the ethics of the people behind this project.”\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eBottom line: \u003c/strong\u003eThe deepfaking of Anthony Bourdain's voice has \u003ca href=\"https://www.newyorker.com/culture/annals-of-gastronomy/the-ethics-of-a-deepfake-anthony-bourdain-voice?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eraised questions\u003c/a\u003e about the ethics of using synthetic media in film, which won’t be resolved soon. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c!-- SOCIAL LINKS --\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" style=\"border-collapse:
